body:
### Problem:
There is no way for a user to tell ":restart" to "run this command(s) after restarting".

### Solution:
All ":restart" args following the optional +cmd arg #34788 are treated as a big cmdline that is passed as a "-c" CLI arg when restarting nvim.

Closes: #34822

comment_data.body: One problem here. If nvim is started with a `-c` arg and someone just attempts `:restart` on its own, that `-c` arg would be considered. But if they call `:restart <cmd>` then that `-c` they used initially would be skipped (two different behaviours). Don't know how to solve it though... Will think about this...

Initial thoughts: Instead of skipping every `-c` arg we could just check for repeats while building argv. That'd handle the problems I guess. Only downside is it makes the implementation a little bit more complex.

Apparently that was not the problem.... It adds a `-c ""` by default if you run only `:restart` which would mean every `-c` arg after would get skipped. This works as intended so I think that's fine.

> Initial thoughts: Instead of skipping every `-c` arg we could just check for repeats while building argv. That'd handle the problems I guess. Only downside is it makes the implementation a little bit more complex.

This doesn't really work because running `:restart <cmd>` and `:restart` consecutively causes it to still include `-c <arg>` from the first restart because its technically not "repeated" in the args passed into nvim.
could you add a 1 line comment that gives a hint about what's going on here
Patching `v:argv` seems like a good approach.
Not obvious why either of these is necessary. What is the intention here?

what happens with a bar? let's add that here if it's supported. it probably should be supported, because it makes no sense for any command to follow `:restart` :)

```suggestion
    tt.feed_data(':restart +qall echo "Hello" | echo "World" \013')
```

comment_data.body: Multiple consecutive `:restart <arg>` would cause the `-c` arg to repeatedly execute when the new server starts which is not the intended functionality (this is also what happens with `--embed` as well (because it gets added in `ui_client_start_server()` iirc))

small examples really avoid a lot of explanation in cases like this. do you mean it will "stack" like this?

```
:restart foo
nvim -c foo
:restart foo
nvim -c foo -c foo
...
```
Yep! Exactly....
what's special about the first `-c` ?

It's always added by the latest `:restart` ...
```
:restart foo
nvim -c foo
:restart bar
nvim -c bar -c foo
```
So we only need the first `-c`

Cases of `:restart` and `:restart <arg>` are handled as well.
```
:restart foo
nvim -c foo
:restart
nvim -c '' -c foo
```
(The actual quotes are not added)

Should the next command be run as a startup arg itself?
like `:restart foo | bar` runs `-c foo -c bar` or `-c foo | bar`

TODO:
Fix: ~https://github.com/neovim/neovim/actions/runs/16488883018/job/46619056499?pr=35045~ Memory leak due to unhandled return of `string_slice()`.

Rebasing will fix the failing oldtest CI.

btw, WDYT about a different approach: instead of patching `VV_ARGV`, 

1. send the `[command]` via the `restart` UI event
2. in `ui_client.c`, run the command via `rpc_send_event(ui_client_channel_id, "nvim_command", ...);`
    - somewhere in [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/93f5bd0caf9037f95ee77288bfd424008bc3a14b/src/nvim/ui_client.c#L333-L342)

that would simplify the logic, and probably be more reliable? we would need to extend the ui event:

```diff
diff --git a/runtime/doc/api-ui-events.txt b/runtime/doc/api-ui-events.txt
index 05c4bb181b22..ec725518aa64 100644
--- a/runtime/doc/api-ui-events.txt
+++ b/runtime/doc/api-ui-events.txt
@@ -251,7 +251,7 @@ the editor.
 	Indicates to the UI that it must stop rendering the cursor. This event
 	is misnamed and does not actually have anything to do with busyness.
 
-["restart", progpath, argv] ~
+["restart", progpath, argv, cmd] ~
 	|:restart| command has been used and the Nvim server is about to exit.
 	The UI should wait for the server to exit, and then start a new server
 	using `progpath` as the full path to the Nvim executable |v:progpath| and
```

> btw, WDYT about a different approach: instead of patching `VV_ARGV`, 
> 1. send the `[command]` via the `restart` UI event
> 2. in `ui_client.c`, run the command via `rpc_send_event(ui_client_channel_id, "nvim_command", ...);`
>     - somewhere in [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/93f5bd0caf9037f95ee77288bfd424008bc3a14b/src/nvim/ui_client.c#L333-L342)

This was kinda what I did initially. The only problem here is in step 1. 

Sending the `[command]` via the UI event would require `remote_ui_restart` to know what arg was passed to `:restart`. This could be solved by adding another global but then I didn't like how it turned out.

I wonder if actually spending some time to refactor out that call to `remote_ui_restart` elsewhere from `getout()` in `main.c` could help... In this case, we could also get rid of the `restarting` global (?). But i am not very sure how I'd go about this.

P.S.: I also think `remote_ui_restart` can directly call `nvim_command`  if it has the `[command]` instead of having it be called from the UI.

> Sending the `[command]` via the UI event would require `remote_ui_restart` to know what arg was passed to `:restart`. ... by adding another global

oh, right. there is a way to avoid it, and even avoid the `restarting` global, by pushing an event+args on the event-loop ([example](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/93f5bd0caf9037f95ee77288bfd424008bc3a14b/src/nvim/event/proc.c#L433)), and event handler reschedules itself if `exiting=false`. not sure if that's better.

> P.S.: I also think `remote_ui_restart` can directly call `nvim_command` if it has the `[command]`

I like the idea of having the *server* eagerly start the new Nvim instance https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34367 . 

1. server (nvim-1) starts new nvim instance (nvim-2)
2. server emits `restart[..., cmd]` ui event
3. ui handler:
    1. opens a channel to nvim-2
    2. waits for nvim-2 to die (close the channel)
4. if the nvim-1 fails to quit:
    - server terminates nvim-2.
    - ui `restart` handler cancels its wait routine when it sees that nvim-2 died.

If the server is running with `--listen` on a socket and the client is attached to that socket, the new server cannot be started until the old server stop listening on the socket. But if the old server stops listening, the client cannot notify it.

Ok, let's start with this. Hopefully we can refine it before 0.12 release. 

Thanks @sathya-pramodh , this is nice!

> 2. in `ui_client.c`, run the command via `rpc_send_event(ui_client_channel_id, "nvim_command", ...);`

I found another problem with this :sweat_smile:, user-defined commands are not accessible at this point if we do `rpc_send_event` because `nvim_command` gets scheduled before the config loads.

Eg: If I have something like this in my `init.lua`
```
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("PostRestart", function()
	vim.cmd("source Session.vim")
	os.remove("Session.vim")
end, {})
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("Restart", function()
	vim.api.nvim_command("restart PostRestart")
end, {})
```

I'd have to replace it with:

```
vim.api.nvim_create_user_command("Restart", function()
	vim.api.nvim_command("restart source Session.vim | lua os.remove('Session.vim')")
end, {})
```

I'm not sure how I'd fix that.

> > 3\. in `ui_client.c`, run the command via `rpc_send_event(ui_client_channel_id, "nvim_command", ...);`
> 
> I found another problem with this 😅, user-defined commands are not accessible at this point if we do `rpc_send_event` because `nvim_command` gets scheduled before the config loads.

`ui_client.c` can decide when to do stuff. It doesn't have to do it immediately. It could wait for attach, or VimEnter, ...
